author: wjmelements
content:
Reposted today's statement on 3403 along with my comments on two new ideas that came up in the call. Please discuss 3403 async if you have a strong opinion on it; don't wait for the next ACD.
https://ethereum-magicians.org/t/eip-3298-removal-of-refunds/5430/28

author: timbeiko
content: Agenda for the next AllCoreDevs **next Friday**: https://github.com/ethereum/pm/issues/301

author: timbeiko
content:
Also, I added a comment to the London timing thread: https://github.com/ethereum/pm/issues/245#issuecomment-821329468 

I'll follow up with the client teams to ask what EIPs could be possible in either timeline, which should help inform what we want to do for the upgrade.

author: vorot93
content: Please don't try to moderate the discussion in which you have a clear profit motive

author: vorot93
content: Especially since you're not a core dev

author: _shemnon
content: That's an unnecessarily divisive way to frame it.

author: vorot93
content: it's the real way to frame it

author: vorot93
content: several bogus proposals (gas tokens in protocol, really) because the man accumulated millions of gastokens about to be turned into dust

author: vorot93
content: now he's trying to steer the whole discussion

author: wjmelements
content: I clearly disclosed my conflict of interest from the start. It's taxing to ACD sync time that the 3403 proponents are not discussing async in the discussions-to. Please keep focus on its merits; most champions will have personal interests in their proposals, else they wouldn't put their time into it.

author: vorot93
content: power plays like this and the community complacency is what makes my faith in ACD process dwindle, and I'm pretty sure not just mine

author: wjmelements
content: I am hoping there will be a discussion so we arrive at the correct decision. There is opposition besides myself, particularly from protocol developers about gas incentives they will optimize around. There are some good ideas bouncing around.

author: vorot93
content: the most taxing thing to ACD time was having to discuss and explicitly reject those bogus proposals

author: vorot93
content: those _protocol developers in opposition_ are mostly in your head, I'm afraid

author: wjmelements
content: I read some of their posts in the call. You're free to respond to them on the forum. But please reduce your hostility to me. We have a lot in common and share similar values.

author: vorot93
content: I will respond where I see fit, thank you. As I said, please don't try to steer discussion of the EIP you're opposed to.

author: pipermerriam
content: Under state-expiry, we differentiate between zero and unset.  This is a change from the current way we use the trie.  Once something is set, I don't believe it can ever go back to unset, and thus, the trie is forced to hold the "zero" value forever.  I'm not 100% certain, but I believe this dictates that we **must** remove refunds for setting things back to zero because under the state expiry scheme, setting things to zero doesn't actually free up storage....
